commits.commitMessage:
Do not check for RC utilities when under Yocto toolchain

Yocto toolchain does not install RC project specific utilities such as
rcPatch. Hence, do not expect them to be present when swidelta is
running from a Yocto toolchain.

This commit adds a function in swidelta to determine if the current
directory is in a Yocto toolchain path iand uses that function to decide
whether to check for RC project utilities. Additional check is added to
return error, if swidelta is attempted to run for and RC target when
under Yocto toolchain.

Note that the check for Yocto toolchain patch is done based on the
presence of string "pokysdk-linux" which could change as Yocto project
evolves.

Resolves: LETOOLS-1199
Change-Id: I9c7dd2936c8c078f27d386daf917dcfcb9041c07
Signed-off-by: Anju Kunjumon <akunjumon@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Do not check for RC utilities when under Yocto toolchain

comments.message:
Could you please have a look at these changes?

Regards
Anju

Hi Tom,

Please find explanation inline. Could you please have a relook?

Regards
Anju

ThreadX also needs hdrcnv, swicwe, awk, bsdiff, etc. So this logic won't work very well. We have several utilities that are needed in multiple platforms, so we have to check their existence all the time.

I think it would be easier if you can figure out how to determine if you are under the Yocto environment, and use "if xxx fi" to wrap around RC-specific utilities so you can skip them.

Hi Tom, the checks for those utilities are kept common and will be executed for both ThreadX and Linux. Only the RC specific checks are moved into a separated function and called (in addition to the common checks) for ThreadX. That way the additional checks will be run only for Threadx and not for Linux. Could you please have a relook?

$TARGET is not set when we run "swidelta -v". In other words, your patch will only check the tools for WP when we run "swidelta -v".

Since swidelta calls check_env() before anything else, I think we need to put the changes inside check_env().

The idea was that:
There are some common, mandatory tools (imgdiff, bsdiff etc.) and some target specific tools (rcPatch etc.). The target specific tools are called only when "-t RC*" is used. This why I moved the check for those tools there.

A check too see if swidelta is executed from within a Yocto toolchain, will look like this:

scriptdir=$(cd $(dirname ${0}); pwd)

is_yocto_toolchain()
{
    if [[ "${scriptdir}" == *pokysdk-linux/* ]]; then
        return $SWI_OK
    else
        return $SWI_ERR
    fi
}

I find it odd to put a Yocto specificity inside swidelta script. But if that is preferred, I can change the patch.

The swidelta bash script checks all kinds of environment all the time, so checking if we are under Yocto is not that odd.

If we can add some comments explaining why we need to skip some tool checks when is_yocto_toochain() is true, then that would be great. It can help future maintainers understand how to handle similar situations.

Hi Tom,

I have uploaded the second solution. That is, skipping RC tools when running from a Yocto toolchain. Personally, I prefer the first one- that is, checking for a RC tools only when they are required.

Please find reply to your last question in line.

Regards
Anju
It is to take care of relative paths.

commits.commitMessage:
Generate META images for unsigned delta packages

We use META images to preserve the original target image CWE headers, so
we can reconstruct the target image with identical CWE headers in Delta
FOTA. However, we forgot to generate META images for unsigned delta
packages, so we always failed to reconstruct unsigned target images.

This patch has fixed this issue in the host-side tools, so we can
generate unsigned delta packages with META images, which allow us to
successfully reconstruct unsigned target images.

Resolves: LE-16419
Change-Id: I75ffe3212b7574982ed5988b9777eb5b3374b40a
commits.subject: Generate META images for unsigned delta packages

commits.commitMessage:
Generate delta patches for the modem image (DSP2)

Delta packages are generated by the swidelta script, which calls the
sdpatch tool to generate delta patches of partition images, including
non-modem images (SBL1, TZON, APPS, etc.) and the modem image (DSP2).

In this patch, we enhanced the sdpatch tool, so that it can generate
delta patches of the modem image (DSP2) using Qualcomm's Q6ZIP
algorithm, which can significantly reduce the delta package size.

Resolves: LE-15228
Change-Id: Ia78975d194823e5680d422f58c9913ec3a93e03e
commits.subject: Generate delta patches for the modem image (DSP2)

commits.commitMessage:
Enhance DOTA host-side tools to handle RC76

The original DOTA host-side tools can only generate WP76 and RC51 delta
packages. By integrating Qualcomm's delta generation scripts and Q6ZIP
compression/decompression library, the host-side tools now can also
generate RC76 delta packages.

Resolves: LE-15227 LE-15228 LE-15229
Change-Id: I0c9d059036665e6e57a66ece246accd236eefa82
commits.subject: Enhance DOTA host-side tools to handle RC76

comments.message: Better if you can use only one script for splitting and decompress. If split script require to call decompressor script, it can call internally, rcPatch should not be aware or keep track of it. That is more streamlined and consistent with software engineering design principle (high cohesion and low coupling)

Qualcomm uses these two scripts, so I don't want to change them. In fact, I change nothing in these two scripts, except renaming them to match the current "RC51xx_Image_Split.py" file name pattern.

I still prefer using the existing code, because refactoring them will take a lot of time and the current code is already working. Beside, if there's anything wrong in these scripts, we can communicate with Qualcomm easily.

Not a good idea to put our internal release folder links in public tool. Please note: this tool can be used by customer for wp76xx/wp77xx. Remove sierra wireless internal build folder reference, rather put some public/releases package reference

commits.commitMessage:
Add host side tool processing for RC51xx

  - Changed swidelta to handle rc51xx spkg
  - Added new tool (rcPatch) to handle individual threadX cwe image. Old
    swidiff can't be used here because they heavily use linux filesystem
    architecture (ubi, squashfs etc) which is no longer valid for
    threadX platform.
  - Added modem splitter python script. This splitter script assumes
    modem image contains clade1/clade2 compressed section, not the
    legacy qualcomm q6zip section.

Resolves: LE-14127
Change-Id: I8d43e1be11ebd4e324bae5de15490e7042664ffd
commits.subject: Add host side tool processing for RC51xx

In __init__(), we do not return value. If we want to express something wrong happened in __init__(), we can raise exceptions. In this case, the most appropriate built-in standard exception is RuntimeError. Therefore, instead of using the print statement, you can say:

comments.message: Maybe we can use $@ and $^ here instead of repeating the prerequisite/target names.

Any reason why we are doing like that?

How this directory (created by mktemp) will be removed specially when mkdelta is killed on purpose/failed? 

This usecase is may be common as mkdelta takes long time, and user may kill it if needed. Also in case of failure, this script doesn't remove the temporary files (mainly for post-mortem debugging and I found it quite useful while working with validation team). These temporary files are removed on next run of mkdelta (however, in this case script doesn't remove the /tmp/tmp.XXXXXXXdeltaTools).


To me having a known path may give a better post-mortem debugging experience.

One issue is that having a common temporary directory means that potentially this tool cannot be run in parallel multiple times on 1 PC. This could lead to issues very hard to debug.

As for the fact that there is no routine sequence to clean-up in this script, that seems like something that should be there. Deletion of that folder on the next run is not really a proper workflow.

Deleting when the script exits is simple:

   cleanup()
   {
      rm -rf "$TEMP_PATH"
   }

   trap cleanup EXIT

This will execute if the script exits normally, or via a signal that the shell handles like SIGINT and SIGTERM.

To keep the temp material for post-mortem debugging, there can be a --keep-temp debug option.

This folder got deleted if mkdelta finishes successfully. But in case of failure this folder wasn't deleted (by using trap command etc) purposefully for post-mortem analysis.

Running mkdelta/imgdiff from multiple shell is a known issue (https://issues.sierrawireless.com/browse/LE-11269 and https://issues.sierrawireless.com/browse/LE-11221), we need more elegant and clever solution (by taking care of the bigger picture) than the quick solutions.

For the time being, I think it is better to remove this fix.

Interestingly, libgen's dirname is robust to receiving a null pointer, and returns "." in that case.

And so then we end up adding "." to the PATH.

I think in our case (if we stick with the argv[0] approach), if we detect a null pointer out of realpath, then we need not do anything with PATH. If the program was found using PATH, then its siblings should likewise be found.
In this pathological condition that is unlikely to arise, we could just take the argument and make that the PATH.

By the way, kind of off topic to this commit:

"which" is not such a hot command to use; it is not standardized by POSIX and various flavors of it exist. It originated in BSD as a shell script that accompanied the C shell (from BSD). 

In POSIX we have the "command" command; specifically for this purpose here, we would use "command -v".

http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/utilities/command.html

commits.commitMessage:
Add dependencies for incremental rebuilding.

* Makefile (COMPILE_C_O): Use gcc's -MMD to generate .d files which
exppress dependencies of the .o on the .c file and local headers.
We also add an -include line to optionally include (i.e. if they exist)
these dependency files.  If the build directory and the files do not
exist, then the -include silently does nothing. Thus when doing a clean
build, we work without dependencies (which doesn't matter since we are
building everything). Subsequent incremental builds have dependencies
due to this include. A minor thing is not handled; if a header file is
removed from the project, an incremental rebuild will fail with
"no rule to make <the removed header>", because the dependency files
still refer to the header, which is now a nonexistent file appearing as
a prerequisite to a .o.

Resolves: LE-11854
Change-Id: Ie9f66dc0d460383144b9be95dc31e6f2cfa356e0
commits.subject: Add dependencies for incremental rebuilding.

commits.commitMessage:
Look for co-located executables and shared libs.

We set up the PATH variable to look for executables in the same
directory where the executable (imgdiff or mkdiff) is installed.

This change serves multiple needs.

Firstly, it addresses the problem of these tools being used directly,
without the toolchain environment script being sourced. As long as
mkdiff is colocated with imgdiff and bsdiff, it can find these tools.

Secondly, when these programs are run from a toolchain installation, the
shared libraries loaded by the shlib module are pulled from the
toolchain's native sysroot, rather than from the host, if possible.
Shared libs from the toolchain native sysroot exactly match what the
tool was built with.

Lastly, this change anticipates the need to use the shared library
version of bsdiff, which will only be available in the toolchain root.

* Makefile (IMGDIFF_OBJS, MKDIFF_OBJS): Include new selfpath.o module.

* imgdiff.c (main): Call selfpath_init. Prepend the self binary path
to the PATH environment variable.

* mkdiff/mkdiff.c (main): Same change as in imgdiff.c.

* selfpath.c: New file. Calculates executable's own path, its bin
directory path, and the sibling lib directory path. Provides a
utility function for prepending a new element to PATH-like environment
variables.

* selfpath.h: New file.

* shlib.c (DLOAD): Macro rewritten to just target the new shlib_dlopen
function.
(STRNULL): New macro.
(catstr, splitstr, freevec): New functions.
(shlib_dlopen): New function: wrapper for dlopen which looks for the
all versions of the library in the selflibdir directory first using a
full absolute path, then falls back on a dlopen with just the short
name.
(shlib_init): Add list of versions to libcrypto, in order of preference.
Lots of comments added.

* shlib.h (shlib_dlopen): Declared.

Resolves: LXSWIREF-987
Change-Id: I0dccb4fb8d8e3c03ad46e91ccd389496de1042af
commits.subject: Look for co-located executables and shared libs.

comments.message:
Why do we need this?

In the toolchain native sysroot, we have libcrypto.so.1.0.2. That's it; no symlinks, no other versions.

On an Ubuntu 18 box, we have these in /usr/lib/x86_64:

* a libcrypto.so which a symlink to libcrypto-1.1.so, which is a binary.

* a libcrypto-1.0.0.so, which is a different binary from libcrypto-1.1.so.

Of these, 1.0.0 is probably what we want in preference to the 1.1 and unsuffixed version.

Simply dlopen("libcrypto.so", ...) will not work against the toolchain sysroot since there is no such file there.

So what we can express here is that when we are searching for our own library co-located with the executable, we will try version ".so.1.0.2" first and then if that is not found then just ".so".  If those fail, then we just ask for system versions of the library: libcrypto.so.1.0.0, then libcrypto.so.1.1, then .1 and then just libcrypto.so.

Why do we need this?

In the toolchain native sysroot, we have libcrypto.so.1.0.2. That's it; no symlinks, no other versions.

On an Ubuntu 18 box, we have these in /usr/lib/x86_64:

* a libcrypto.so which a symlink to libcrypto-1.1.so, which is a binary.

* a libcrypto-1.0.0.so, which is a different binary from libcrypto-1.1.so.

Of these, 1.0.0 is probably what we want in preference to the 1.1 and unsuffixed version.

Simply dlopen("libcrypto.so", ...) will not work against the toolchain sysroot since there is no such file there.

So what we can express here is that when we are searching for our own library co-located with the executable, we will try version ".so.1.0.2" first and then if that is not found then just ".so".  If those fail, then we just ask for system versions of the library: libcrypto.so.1.0.0, then libcrypto.so.1.1, then .1 and then just libcrypto.so.

commits.commitMessage:
Load libcrypto explicitly using dlopen.

A new source file shlib.c is added which implements wrappers
around libraries needed by imgdiff.c that cause versioning
problems.

The main function in imgdiff.c is modified to call shlib_init.

In the Makefile, we no longer link imgdiff with -lcrypto,
but we do need to link -ldl to get dlopen. Also, shlib.o is included in
imgdiff.

Zlib is deliberately untreated; imgdiff continues to link with -lz.

Resolves: LE-11793
Change-Id: I4775c3ff17e4f0e9256a234b9a3336b1e668a129
commits.subject: Load libcrypto explicitly using dlopen.

comments.message: So If a new function is used, then it should be declared here? Why are we convoluting it so much?

Yes, and because releasing binaries is hard.

BTW, I wonder if we need to put that mechanism in place for libz.
The properly is mainly with libcrypto, so I think we could keep the normal usage for libz.

Declaring those functions here with this macro is a breeze. If we use a new function from, we will get an unresolved symbol error, then just add it.  There probably aren't going to be hundreds of new functions.

It could be easier, but probably not without additional build tooling beyond the C preprocessor.

I did have this for the SHA256 stuff from libcrypto only at first; then I threw in the libz functions for a kind of consistency. (Plus, the more times a preprocessor macro is called, the better it is justified, haha).

We can easily remove those libz-related definitions, and put -lz back into the Makefile.

Patch Set 3:

Bertrand says:
> This solution seems a bit hardcore to me, seems like a weird route to take.

I suspect that my sweeping Makefile changes are making it look more complicated than it is. Most of them are just to "beef up" the build system and are worthwhile on their own. I could make a separate commit out of that. In fact, I will do just that now.

I do have another idea regarding the shared libs. The tools could dlopen() the libraries they use, and get the needed functions via dlsym(). The functions will be called through wrappers that look like the original API (and can be generated via preprocessing). It's a kind of "standard practice" on Windows ages ago, for using newer API's that might not exist in older Windows (where the program also runs).

(With this approach we can accurately deal with any library with just about any versioning issue, because dlvsym() can be used instead of dlsym() to pull a specific version of a library symbol and the program can use the matching version of the library's header files.)

comments.message:
Does this .orig file have to be in the repo?

If it is the ancestor of "mkdiff.c", can we just make a commit where "mkdiff.c" is this ancestor, and then another commit which updates it to the current version?

Somehow, we will have to spin 64 and 32 bit versions of these executables.

We support 32 bit and 64 bit toolchains.

In the case of swiflash and swicwe, the .zip files provide both 32 and 64 bit binaries for Linux; the Yocto recipes choose which ones based on the toolchain's architecture.

Mildly annoying, I know!

If we look at the swicwe Makefile here:

http://cgit-legato/tools/swicwe/tree/Makefile

you can see the are not trying to build both architectures at the same time. But the Makefile does detect the arch being built and puts the executables into separate linux32/ or linux64/ build directories as appropriate.

This lets them just run the build in the same directory using two different toolchains, and then package up the results.
Is there some deep reason why the name of mkdelta is configurable via a variable, but these other targets are not?
No deep reason, except easy handling of path change of  mkdelta in the imgdiff  directory.

There is no need for this to be a .PHONY target; this rule's target can just make $(BUILD_DIR)/imgdiff, and so the -o argument can be -o $@, as usual.

The way it is, every time you run make, it will rebuild this tool, even if it is up-to-date with respect to the source files.

The dependency between a phony target and source files is useless because the source files always exist, and the phony target never exists.
I tried removal of phony but seems it makes the extension of makefile complicated.

Where is the "$(MKDELTA): " rule? Because we don't have one, we are relying on a built-in inference rule: make understands that we want to build "mkdelta", and it discovers by itself that there is a "mkdelta.c" in the filesystem. So then it runs an internal build recipe like $(CC) mkdelta.c -o mkdelta.   But then, this recipe doesn't have the -Wall and -Werror that we are putting into the other rules, nor the -D_GNU_SOURCE.
mkdelta is a script, not a source file
Is a mkdiff already made in the top-level Makefile?
Good pick. This can be removed. I will remove it
I took it from 3rd party directory and want to keep it intact

Do we really need this file ?
As I saw, the patch_utils.c only use LE_OK or LE_FAULT return code. Why do not use 0 (LE_OK) and -1 (LE_FAULT) instead.
Like it. Good idea. Will remove

Perhaps better to use option -p to preserve the mode and time and other. Else, we cannot predict which mode will be set by default.
Why do not use install ?

Can we remove the -s (strip) here?

Already stripped binaries coming out of a build are flagged by Yocto:

ERROR: nativesdk-imgdiff-1.0-r0 do_package: QA Issue: File '/opt/swi/y22-ext/sysroots/x86_64-pokysdk-linux/usr/bin/imgdiff' from nativesdk-imgdiff was already stripped, this will prevent future debugging! [already-stripped]

We will have to add cruft to the recipe to suppress the already-stripped check.

Above, can we make a third variable like this:

   ARCH_NAME := x86_64
   ...
   ARCH_NAME := i686

Then the .zip files can be:

   deltaTools-$(ARCH_STRING).zip

This is helpful on the Yocto side.

A version name is also needed. That doesn't have to be assigned by this makefile, but for the download from the website, it will have to be somewhere in the URL. Might as well be in the name. It could come from a $(VERSION) variable (that someone has to remember to increment when they tag a new version in git).


Like:

   DELTA_TOOLS := deltaTools-$(VERSION)-$(ARCH_NAME)

Examples of names:

   deltaTools-1.0-i686.zip
   deltaTools-1.3-x86_64.zip

The above looks much like a widely-used convention in GNU/Linux distros which is good.

Are we going to have two .zip files: deltaTools32.zip and deltaTools64.zip? From the Yocto perspective, that is fine; it can easily fetch both. Or possibly just the one it needs for the SDK architecture it's building.

Are you dropping the dependency on libbz2 and libssl? Interesting.

If so, we can drop that from the Yocto recipe also.

I've never used CURDIR in my life!

This recipe line is equivalent to just

  rm -rf build* *.zip

because CURDIR is the current working directory in which Make runs commands.

This will work even if someone invokes the makefile from another directory using "make -C /path/to/project"; the variable is set based on the current directory after all -C options are processed.

CURDIR might be useful in situations when we change out of the build directory with cd and then in the same recipe line we want to refer back to materials in the build directory.

Using file name wild cards in "make clean" is dangerous. We are removing anything matching build* and *.zip, regardless of whether the Makefile actually built that item.

If you saved something in a file called build-debug-log, it's gone. :)
Any chance we can get this file from a toolchain or somewhere instead of copying it in this closed-source repository?

commits.commitMessage:
[klocwork] Fix klocwork issues in imgdiff

Imgdiff code skeleton is taken from google imgdiff which doesn't
follow our coding standard, hence there were some resource leak
(memory/fd etc). These issues are addressed here.

Resolves: LE-11345
Change-Id: Iccdc1813a5cae79df0f8c044983528a0faccfd88
commits.subject: [klocwork] Fix klocwork issues in imgdiff

Doesn't make much sense here, hence it should be ignored. As per this error doc (https://support.roguewave.com/documentation/klocwork/en/2017/sv.tainted.path_traversal/) absolute path should be considered as error, however, this mkdelta and imgdiff requires creating large amount of temporary files that are created in /tmp/ directory and they have to be accessed via absolute path
I think the point Klocwork is making is that we need to validate if the input path is actually what we expect (for example, /tmp directory, absolute path, etc.)
Sorry i misunderstood the issue. Now got it. Done.

Sonar [BLOCKER c:S3584]

> Review the data-flow; this memory allocation might not have been released when going out of scope.
False positive. Exit will clear all allocated memory

If we don't "free", we are relying on the OS to do resource clean-up.  And the OS might not do that.  Also, if the program runs long, it will eat up memory (i.e. memory leak).  The same applies to all other similar comments for malloc.

This a host tool (like mktools). These memories are allocated  in main function (not any sub function, hence no chance of memory leak) and they requires till the main function exits. Exit of main function should deallocate these memories.

I agree that this being a host tool, and the run time is typically short, the risk of not freeing memory is low.  However the flip side of the coin is also that the effort of adding the "free" is also low, so we should do it for the good practice.

Yes using free is a good programming practices and the effort is typically low. But, a complicated algorithm like here, it isn't trivial and can introduce subtle pitfalls. This imgdiff maintains a tree of allocated memory chunks. Based on chunk type (squashfs-entry/zip-entry) memory allocation pattern may varies. Properly deallocation requires traversing all the data structures and do deallocation as per individual chunk entry. This will require good amount of effort to do it properly (probably doesn't makes much sense to put such effort only for good practice)

I'm sorry to say that I think you should fix this. I know it is a pain, but you should probably replace your multiple exits(1) with a single exit() at the end, and use goto. Then at that single exit point simply free all your allocated pointers.

Group them all at the top, set them to NULL.
Allocate them as you go. 
Then free the entire set at the single exit point. 
Add a comment on the block of pointers saying "if you add any allocated memory, remember to free at the exit point".

I know it's a pain, but it shuts up Sonar - and somebody could take this code and copy it into a longer running program. Sorry, not the answer you wanted :).

No. It is complaining about paths are used without validation. For more details, please look: https://support.roguewave.com/documentation/klocwork/en/2017/sv.tainted.path_traversal/

As solution, I used realpath(this checks and returns canonical path, manpage: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/realpath.3.html), however, klocwork failed to detect it and still throw error.
To initialize, you could use also char var[PATH_MAX+1] = { 0, };

I need to initialize all character to zero. 
char var[PATH_MAX+1] = {0} should be enough (Ref: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2589749/how-to-initialize-array-to-0-in-c)

char** src_path ...

*src_path = realpath(argv[1], *src_path);


That seems to be the part that klocwork is missing.

Not really, according to: https://support.roguewave.com/documentation/klocwork/en/2017/sv.tainted.path_traversal/

It appears that it complains about being able to pass any path without checking. It doesn't like the possibility of '../' (up-directory), '%00' (null-character), or leading '/' in filenames due to security concerns. I actually agree with the concern and if it's not much work, it's worth fixing.

There is an example of fixed code on the same page, albeit not much descriptive.

The issue here isn't the security risk, path canonicalized/neutralize logic is already there(done by c built-in API realpath(), see implementation section: http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/22.html#Detection%20Methods), however klocwork is throwing this message as it failed to detect it.

commits.commitMessage:
Initial commit of modified sources and a README.

This is a modified version of Android imgdiff with the goal of handling squashfs
images with differing numbers of chunks.

Currently, it identifies identical chunks, matches up the rest of the chunks
based on minimal diff size, but does not output this information to any file.

Resolves: STUDY-1257
Change-Id: If39b86ca2e285bc890865910b72dd3eaae08bc00
commits.subject: Initial commit of modified sources and a README.
